metadata.title: Efficient and Stable Silicon Photocathodes Coated with a Vertically Standing Nano-MoS2 Films for Solar Hydrogen Production

sections.text:
1
intense research, which converts sunlight into hydrogen energy. Silicon is suitable as a viable light-harvesting material for constructing such cell, however needs to improve its stability and explore cheap and efficient co-catalyst. Here we fabricate highly
efficient and stable photocathodes by integrating crystalline MoS2 catalyst with ∼2nm Al2O3 protected n +p-Si. Al2O3 acts as both protective and passivative layer of the Si surface, while the sputtering method using a MoS2 target along with a post-annealing leads to a vertically standing, conformal and crystalline nano-MoS2 layer on Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode. Efficient (0.4 V vs. RHE onset potential and 35.6 mA/cm2 saturated photocurrent measured under 100 mA/cm2 Xe lamp illumination) and stable (above 120 h continuous water splitting) photocathode was obtained, which opens the door for the MoS2 catalyst to be applied in photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution in a facile and scalable way.
KEYWORDS: photocathode, silicon, MoS2 catalyst, photoelectrochemical properties, Al2O3 layer

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The fabrication of efficient, stable and cheap photocathodes is important in photoelectrochemical (PEC) H2 generation. 1,2 Silicon (band-gap ~1.12 eV) is an suitable semiconductor for photocathode since it is rich on earth and absorbs a significant fraction of the solar energy and the position of its conduction band edge is higher than the potential of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during water splitting.3 However, there are two challenges of utilizing Si for HER. One is that Si is easily oxidized during the PEC reaction due to the oxygen in the solution, and the electrically insulating SiO2 will result in device failure. 4,5 Therefore, thin protective layers such as TiO2, Al2O3 and Ni/NiOx are used to suppress the oxidation while the interfacial charge transfer of photogenerated carriers is allowed.5-8 Another challenge is that the HER kinetics on the Si electrode surface is rather slow. Pt is reported as the efficient and stable catalyst for the photocathodes. However, it is a rare and expensive resource. For solar hydrogen production to be cost competitive, the HER catalysts need to be efficient, inexpensive and scalable.9
Recently, many new classes of inorganic HER catalysts have been reported,
composed of only Earth-abundant elements.10 However, coupling these catalysts onto photocathodes is less studied. In addition to the synthetic difficulties, such coupling is challenging because in many cases the photoelectrodes and catalysts are chemically incompatible, which induces interfacial defects and stability issues.11 Several groups have recently tried to load the photocathodes with non-noble metal catalysts for efficient H2 generation, 7,12,13 however, the stability and PEC reactivity are far from satisfactory. Fabrication of low-cost, stable and efficient photocathodes for practical applications needs further research.
Molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) has been studied as the most attractive candidate for cheap HER electrocatalyst.14-18 The bulk MoS2 is not catalytic, but its edge site shows highly catalytic activity.17,19 Therefore, producing MoS2 with morphologies that can maximize catalytically active edge sites has been of great interest. Recently, molybdenum sulfide catalysts have been incorporated on Si photocathode

successfully by different methodologies such as simple dropcasting,20 electrodeposition,21 or sulfidization of Mo.22 However, their chemical stability and PEC performance are far from perfect. Typically, Seger et al. electrodeposited amorphous MoSx on Ti-protected n +p-Si photocathode. 0.33 V vs. RHE (RHE: Reversible Hydrogen Electrode; V vs. RHE: VRHE) onset potential and 16 mA/cm 2 saturated photocurrent were obtained under red light with AM1.5 cut-off (<635 nm) and intensity of 38.6 mW/cm2, and one-hour stability of the photocathode was proved.21 Using a thin Mo/MoS2 protecting layer and [Mo3S13] 2- nanoclusters as surface catalyst, Benck et al. showed an 0.4 VRHE onset potential, 100h stability, however, a low saturated photocurrent of 17.5 mA/cm2 for the n+p-Si photocathode, measured under one sun simulated solar illumination.22
We reported recently the PEC properties of the Al2O3-thin-layer protected and Pt
catalyzed n+p and np+ Si photocathodes.8, 23 In this work we made a further step to explore how to integrate the MoS2 with Si photocathode efficiently. We fabricate highly efficient and stable photocathodes by integrating a MoS2 layer catalyst with ∼2nm Al2O3 protected n +p-Si. Vertically standing, conformal and crystalline nano-MoS2 films were prepared on the Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathodes by a sputtering method using MoS2 as target followed by a post-annealing. In addition to the passivative effect to the Si surface for solar cell and PEC photoelectrode,23-25 Al2O3 in this study also protects the Si surface from the formation of interfacial layer during the MoS2 fabrication. As a result, an onset potential of 0.4 VRHE and a 35.6 mA/cm 2 saturated photocurrent were obtained under 100 mA/cm2 Xe lamp illumination. At 0 VRHE, the photocurrent can exceed 32.4 mA/cm 2. In addition, the electrode exhibited long-time stability under 120 h continuous HER and 160-minute ultrasonication in the electrolyte. Such high efficiency and stability offers a promising pathway towards sustainable hydrogen production for MoS2 catalyzed Si photocathodes.

(156×156×0.018 mm3, 1-3 Ω•cm specific resistance, Canadian Solar Inc.) were used for this work. The fabrication processes of the surface pyramid texture was previously reported. 8 The surface n+p junction was formed on the p-type Si by doping in a POCl3 vapor phase in a tube furnace under atmospheric pressure. Phosphor-silicate glass was removed by reactive ion etching and Al back electrode was then fabricated.8 Finally, the samples were cut into 1.5×1.5 cm2 by a laser.
Before use, Si electrodes were washed by sonication in water, acetone, and
ethanol for 15 minutes one by one. The native SiO2 layer on the Si electrode surface was removed by sonicating the electrodes in a 5 wt % HF solution for 10 min. The Si electrodes were then rinsed in deionized water which was degassed by ultrasonic clearing machine (i-Quip, Aladdin) and dried under a stream of N2.
Preparation of Al2O3 onto Silicon Substrates. The Al2O3 protective layer was
deposited in a layer-by-layer fashion onto the top n+p Si electrode by an InPassion (SoLayTec) atomic layer deposition (ALD) system. The deposition was performed using successive pulses of trimethylaluminum (TMA) and deionized water as the precursors under a nitrogen carrier gas in a vacuum chamber. 8 During the ALD process, 200 ms TMA and 100 ms water precursor pulses were used as one cycle, following with a N2 purge for 10 s after each pulse. The deposition temperature was set to be 200 0C. The number of ALD cycles is 20 and the growth rate is ∼1.0 Å per cycle. The film thickness of ~2 nm, which was measured using transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
Magnetron Sputtering Deposition of MoS2 Film. MoS2 film was prepared
using a magnetron sputtering setup (Kurt J Lesker, PVD 75), deposited from MoS2 targets in a ultra-high vacuum chamber. The MoS2 target was fabricated based on MoS2 power (Aldrich, purity 99%). The base pressure before sputtering was < 5×10 -7 Pa, the pressure during deposition was kept at 2 Pa using a constant Ar-flow of 30 sccm, and substrate temperature and RF power were set to 400 °C and 70W,
respectively. The growth rate of MoS2 layer was ∼1 nm per minute, resulting in a thickness of 67 nm after 60 min deposition. The as-prepared MoS2 was subsequently post-annealed in Ar atmosphere at 800 °C for 30 min for improving its crystallinity.

Sample characterization. We used a field-emission scanning electron
microscope (SEM，SU8010, Hitachi) to observe the surface microstructure after an Au layer was coated to avoid surface charging. Cross-sectional transmission electron microscope (TEM) analysis were performed by a Tecnai G220 (S-TWIN, FEI) operating at 200 kV. For X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements, we used a spectrometer hemispherical analyzer (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo) where the obtained binding energies were referenced to the absorbed carbon at 284.6 eV. X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D/MAX-2000PC, Japanese Rigaku) operating under parallel beam mode with Cu Kα radiation was used to character the crystal structure. A confocal LabRAM spectrometer (HR800, Jobin Yvon, 532 nm excitation laser) was used to obtain Raman spectra. A UV-VIS-NIR spectrophotometer (UV-3600, Shimadzu) was for the optical properties.
Electrochemical measurement. The sealing of the sample, the light source and
the details of electrochemical measurements are the same that we previously reported.8 We controlled the light intensity at 100 mW/cm2 before the light enters into the PEC cell. A Newport optical power meter was used to measure the light intensity. Note the light intensity decreases a little to 93 mW/cm2 after the light goes through the quartz window and this light intensity is close to the one obtained by the photocathode. During the electrochemical measurements, a solution containing 1 M HClO4 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Analytical reagent) with pH=0 was used as the electrolyte. The potentials were modulated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI600D, CH Instrument) and re-scaled to the ones VRHE according to the following equation: VRHE =VAg/AgCl+0.197 V at pH=0. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the samples were measured at a constant -0.25 VRHE with frequency changing from 1 Hz to 100 MHz. The Mott-Schottky plots were carried out at 1000 Hz with applied 10 mV sinusoidal perturbations, while the potential was swept from -0.1 to 0.7 VRHE in a three-electrode cell under illumination.

Figure 1. Top-down SEM images of crystalline MoS2 layer on Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathodes produced by magnetron sputtering for different times: (a) 0 min, (b) 20 min, (c) 60 min and (d) 80 min. (e) Cross-section TEM micrograph of the 60 min sample and (f) the high-resolution TEM image around the MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si interfaces.
The photocathode is constructed on p-type single-crystal silicon. Micropyramid
structure was firstly fabricated by a standard process of alkaline etching in order to improve the light-harvesting ability. An n+p surface junction was then fabricated onto the p-type Si. Subsequently, a thin Al2O3 layer (∼2nm) was deposited on the top n +p electrode surface by a standard ALD process. Finally, MoS2 film was prepared by magnetron sputtering using MoS2 as target in an ultra-high vacuum chamber, followed by a post-annealing process in Ar atmosphere for crystallinity. Note magnetron sputtering is an industrial-scale method to deposit thin film coatings for a large variety of different materials and applications.26,27 Figures 1a-1d present the surface SEM pictures of the crystalline MoS2 layer deposited on Al2O3/n +p-Si with different deposition time. Before the MoS2 deposition, the clear surface of the Al2O3/n +p-Si with micropyramid structure can be observed in Figures 1a and S1a. After 20 min deposition by magnetron sputtering, small particles (∼20 nm) appear uniformly on the sample surface (Figure 1b). Low magnification images of sample surface can be found in Figure S1b. As the sputtering time increases to 60 min, Figure 1c shows vertically standing grass-like nanowires with a diameter about 10 nm. The

surface of Al2O3/n +p-Si is uniformly covered by MoS2 layer (Figure S1c). When the sputtering time increases to 80 min, the growth direction of the MoS2 nanowires will be all in a muddle along with some clusters stacked on the previous grown MoS2, as shown in Figure 1d and S1d. The diameter of these clusters is about 200 nm ~ 400nm.
TEM shown in Figure 1e illustrates that a conformal thin film of MoS2 with a
thickness about 67 nm covers the sample surface when the sputtering time is 60 min. Two different growth modes for MoS2 are found along the vertical direction of substrate. On its surface region with a thickness about 25 nm, vertically standing MoS2 microstructure is present (see more clearly in Figure S2), consistent with the SEM observation in Figure 1c. On the MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si interface region, the vertically microstructure is not observed. Figure 1f is the corresponding high-resolution TEM picture close to MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si interfaces. The layered structures of the crystalline MoS2 can also be observed. However, they seem to be parallel to the substrate surface. The layer distance of ∼0.67 nm corresponds to the (001) face of MoS2, which is in good agreement with the value for bulk MoS2. 28 MoS2 and Si are separated by a very thin (∼2 nm) Al2O3 layer. The element scan during TEM confirms this point (see supporting materials, Figure S3). Our previous work about the Al2O3-protected Si photocathodes illustrated that such thin Al2O3 layer allows electrons tunnel through freely and can also passivate the Si surface, leading to the increase of the minority carrier lifetimes.8 Here, we show that the presence of the Al2O3 makes the Si surface stable and inhibits the oxidation of Si and/or intermixture of Mo and S with Si during the deposition of MoS2. 28 This is very important to keep the photocathode work, since we will show in the following that the photocurrent is very small when the MoS2 film is grown on the Si substrate directly, due to the generation of a SiO2 layer with thickness above 10 nm.

To explore the composition and chemical state of the surface layer, XPS
measurements were taken. In Figure 2a, two peaks located at 229.2 eV and 232.4 eV are originated form Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 orbitals, which confirm the existence of Mo4+ in the layer. Figure 2b is for the S 2p region, where a single doublet of 2p3/2 at 162.1 eV and 2p1/2 at 163.3eV can be observed, corresponding to -2 oxidation state of S. Such results confirm the formation of MoS2 as previously reported. 29, 30 From Raman spectrum we can see the bond structures of the MoS2 film. In Figure 2c, two dominant Raman peaks at 382 and 408 cm-1 are obtained, which are originated from in-plane E12g and out-of-plane A1g vibrations of Mo-S bonds, respectively. This further confirms the formation of MoS2. 31 Its crystal structures and phase identity are characterized by XRD. In Figure 2d, the catalyst displays some peaks at 2θ = 32°, 57° and 68°, matching well with the peaks for the (100), (110) and (200) planes of hexagonal structure of MoS2 (JCPDS Card No. 75-1539), indicating the polycrystalline nature of the MoS2 film.

Figure 3a shows the photocurrent density vs. potential (J-V) scans for MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathodes under illumination. Here we defined the onset potential (Vonset) of photocurrent as the potential which drives the photocurrent to -1 mA/cm2. For the bare Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode, J increases gradually from 0 to 34.6 mA/cm2 when VRHE changes from about -0.03 to -0.8 VRHE, and then saturates. For the MoS2 decorated Al2O3/n +p-Si electrodes, the J-V curves right-shift obviously with the increase of sputtering time. Among these samples, the photocathode with the 60 min MoS2 exhibits the best performance: 0.4 VRHE Vonset and 35.6 mA/cm 2 saturated photocurrent (Jsc), attributed to the loading of a high-quality MoS2 layer with vertically standing grass-like nanowires which provide more activity sites for PEC

HER as shown in Figure 1c. In addition, the band structure of MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si is also favorable to move the photogenerated electrons from Si to MoS2 (Figure S4). However, when the sputtering time increases to 80 min, both the Vonset and Jsc decrease, to 0.39 VRHE and 32.2 mA/cm 2, respectively. There are two main reasons for these decreases of PEC performance. First, increasing the sputtering time of MoS2 can partially change the MoS2 nanowires into some clusters as shown in Figure 1d, which brings about the decrease of catalytic sites and the subseuqent PEC performance. Second, increasing of the MoS2 thickness on Si electrode surface may lower the light absorption of Si, then decrease the photocurrent density. In order to demonstrate such possibility, we purposely grew MoS2 films on transparent indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass substrates using the same sputtering processes to examine its optical and PEC properties. The UV-Vis absorption spectra of ITO glass substrates with and without the decoration of 60 min MoS2 film (Figure S5a) clearly show that MoS2 films has absorption in the 300-900 nm wavelength region, due to the fact that the MoS2 has a bandgap of 1.3eV. 32 In addition, the MoS2 layer on ITO shows no PEC reactivity except for its electrochemical ability (Figure S5c). Therefore, thicker MoS2 layer will reduce the PEC performance of the electrode. Note MoS2 on ITO exhibit similar microstructure as the one deposited on Al2O3/n +p-Si substrate (Figure S5e and S5f).
One puzzle here is the 35.6 mA/cm2 saturated photocurrent obtained from the ∼60 nm MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode, while the MoS2 is very absorbing. This value is confirmed for several times and close to the one without MoS2. To further justify this photocurrent density, we measured the incident photo to charge carrier efficiency (IPCE) of both MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si and Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathodes working under the saturated photocurrent. Figure S6 shows that the IPCE values for MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si are slightly smaller than those of Al2O3/n +p-Si between 670-800 nm, however, slightly higher when the light wavelength is below 450 nm. This results in the close saturated photocurrent of the two samples. We note that similar phonomenon has been reported in 40-60 nm MoSexCly coated n +p-Si with same surface pyramid texture, where MoSexCly shows strong absortion on ITO, however

the saturated photocurrent exceeds 35 mA/cm2 for MoSexCly/n +p-Si photocathode.32 Such phonomenon may be due to the following factors: (1) The coatings suppress the total reflection of the Si surface, as shown in Figure S7(e). This leads to increase of the light intensity obtained by the photocathodes; (2) As reported by King et al, chemically exfoliated pure MoS2 on FTO can generate PEC current. 33 Here the photogenerated electrons/holes in the MoS2 coatings on Si may be separated partially, which contribute to the photocurrent. The band structure shown in Figure S4 for MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si seems to facilitate such process. (3) High electrocatalytic activity of the coatings may make the photogenerated carriers transfer efficiently in the electrode, and then reduce the recombination of the carriers and more photogenerated carriers contribute to the photocurrent.
Figure S5 also shows that the post-annealing of MoS2 leads to the improved catalytic effect. To further confirm this point and also to verify whether MoS2 on FTO is a valid control sample for the catalytic activity, we deposited MoS2 on p +n-Si substrate, where the p+n junction is worked under the forward-biased condition when the catalytic current is measured, and thus Si substrate is conductive. The detailed results are presented in Figure S7. Without the protection of Al2O3, no catalytic effect is found no matter whether the sample is post-annealed or not, indicating again that the foramtion of interfacial layer blockes the transfer of carriers between MoS2 and Si. MoS2 on Al2O3/p +n-Si shows the obvious catalytic activity, however the cathodic current is less than that on ITO, which may be due to the larger electric resistance of the Al2O3/p +n-Si substrate. Figure S7 also shows that the surface microstructures and optical reflection of MoS2 on p +n-Si, Al2O3/p +n-Si with and without post-annealing have no significant changes. However, post-annealing is beneficial for improving the catalytic activity of MoS2 and then the PEC activity of MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode (Figure S7f).
Thin Al2O3 layer deposited by a ALD method was found to be an excellent
protective and passivative layer for Si photocathodes during PEC water splitting.8,23 In order to research the role of Al2O3 in current MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode, we tested J-V curves for n+p-Si electrodes having the 67 nm MoS2 layer and the 2 nm

Al2O3 or not. The bare n +p-Si photocathode has a Vonset at -0.21 VRHE and Jsc at 34 mA/cm2. After coating the Al2O3 layer, the onset potential of the n +p-Si electrode right-shifts obviously to 0.03 VRHE, while the Jsc increases a little to 34.7 mA/cm 2. Coating the MoS2 on Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode results in further impoved PEC properties as discussed above. However, when the MoS2 is fabricated on the naked n +p-Si electrode, Figure 3b shows very small photocurrent, beginning at -0.56 VRHE. At -1.0 VRHE, it is only 4.3 mA/cm 2, indicating that the photocathode does not work nearly. This is originated from the generation of an amorphous interfacial SiO2 layer (~10 nm) between Si and MoS2 film. The HRTEM shown in Figure 3c proves this point. The TEM element scan shown in Figure S8 confirms the existence of this amorphous layer and an additional diffused Si-Mo-S-O layer. Without the protection of Al2O3, the residual oxygen in the deposition chamber may oxidize Si during film deposition. In addition, the intermixture of Mo and S with Si happens during the initial sputtering of MoS2 in vacuum. The high-energy Mo-S-O materials originated from sputtering may bomb the substrate surface, resulting in such interface layer. Therefore, the role of the
∼2 nm Al2O3 layer is not only the passivative effect which increases the minority carrier lifetime on the Si surface according to the previous studies, but also to inhibit the generation of the interfacial layer during the fabrication of MoS2 layer.

The semicircles of high frequency range on the left are nearly the same, indicating that they are originated from the same n+p-Si junction. The second semicircle of low frequency range on the right changes obviously after the loading of MoS2. MoS2 catalyst changes the HER rate at the electrode/electrolyte interface, leading to the smaller diameter of the second circle. This corresponds to a smaller resistance for charge transfer and faster HER rate at the electrode/electrolyte interface,34 illustrating the excellent catalytic effect of the vertically standing nano-MoS2 layer.
To further compare the electrochemical performance, the corresponding
Mott-Schottky plots were drawn as the potential is changed from -0.1 to 0.7 VRHE. The flat band potential (Vfb) is determined by extrapolating the capacitance to zero. 35 In Figure 4b, we obtain an Vfb of 0.42 VRHE for the MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode, whereas the corresponding one for Al2O3/n +p-Si is 0.19 VRHE. Basically, Vonset can be close to Vfb if the HER overpotential is low enough. 36 From Figure 3, we obtain that the Vonset of the two electrodes are 0.4 and 0.03 VRHE, respectively. Compared with 0.19 V for the Al2O3/n +p-Si, much smaller overpotential (0.02V) exists for the MoS2 decorated electrode, suggesting again that the nano-MoS2 layer lowers the HER overpotential. The large difference between Vonset and Vfb for the Al2O3/n +p-Si may also be due to that the catalytic activity of electrode surface without a catalyst is low and the barrier height determined by the EIS measurement is not accurate.

Figure 5. (a) PEC stability measurements for the 67 nm MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode during H2 generation. Inset: J-V curves with 0 and 120 h PEC reaction. (b) J-V curves for the 67 nm MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode after different ultrasonication time.
In addition to high efficiency, long-term stability is an important prerequisite for
a future PEC cell. To check the stability of the MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode, long-time PEC measurements were taken. The small fluctuation of the current shown in Figure 5a is attributed to the nucleation and release of the H2 bubbles on the electrode surface. The HER current does not decrease after 120 h testing, indicating the superior stability of the photocathode. The inset in Figure 5a displays that the difference between the two J-V curves after 0 and 120 h PEC reaction is small, again illustrating the high stability of this photocathode. This is due to the high stability of the as-prepared crystalline nano-MoS2, and also to its good adhesion to Al2O3/n +p-Si. To check this point, we performed the PEC measurements after the electrode experiences ultrasonication. The photocathode was transferred to a glass vial containing water, followed by ultrasonication carried out at a frequency of 40 kHz and a power of 300 W. The J-V curves are taken down after ultrasonicating with different time. Figure 5b shows the J-V curves left-shift quite slowly as the time increases. After 160 min, the photocurrent at 0 VRHE decreases slightly, from 35 to 34.6 mA/cm 2.
In Figure S9 we show the actual amount of hydrogen along with the half of the
calculated electrons which go through the outer circuit. The efficiency in term of
hydrogen produced per electron (Faradaic efficiency) of ∼96% is achieved under illumination. The recombination of carriers on the electrode/electrolyte interface and backward reaction between H2 and O2 may cause the difference between the ideal 100% value and the true Faradaic efficiency.37
MoSx catalyst is usually fabricated on Si electrodes by employing a
electrodeposition procedure.38,39 Here we also electrodeposited MoSx on the present Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode in order to make a stability comparison. The details of the electrodeposition of MoSx can be found in Supporting Information. The film composition and surface morphology are presented in Figure S10a to S10c, indicating

the formation of MoS2 on the electrode surface. Comparing with the pure Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode, Figure S10d shows that the J-V curve for the electrodeposited MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si right-shifts obviously and shows onset potential of 0.18 VRHE and saturated photocurrent of 34.5 mA/cm2, illustrating the catalytic role of the electrodeposited MoS2. Then we performed PEC measurements when the electrode is under the same ultrasonication. The J-V curve left-shifts obviously only after 2 min ultrasonication (Figure S10d), and it is close to the one of pure Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode, indicating that nearly all of the electrodeposited MoS2 gets rid of the electrode surface and its adhesion to Al2O3/n +p-Si electrode is quite poor. This sharp contrast again manifests the high stability of present crystalline nano-MoS2 layer prepared by sputtering plus post-annealing.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: In summary, the MoS2/Al2O3/n +p-Si photocathode presented herein showed both high efficiency and stability for solar hydrogen production. A high-quality MoS2 layer with vertically standing grass-like nanowires was produced by an industrial scale method, magnetron sputtering, leading to more active sites for PEC reaction. Simultaneously, Al2O3 acts as both protective and passivative layer for Si surface during MoS2 deposition. As a result, 0.4 VRHE Vonset, 35.6 mA/cm 2 Jsc and 120 h stability were achieved for Si photocathode. These strategies provide helpful guidelines on how to obtain high activity using cheap and stable materials.

metadata.abstractText: Water splitting in a photoelectrochemical cell has recently received intense research, which converts sunlight into hydrogen energy. Silicon is suitable as a viable light-harvesting material for constructing such cell, however needs to improve its stability and explore cheap and efficient co-catalyst. Here we fabricate highly efficient and stable photocathodes by integrating crystalline MoS2 catalyst with ∼2nm Al2O3 protected n p-Si. Al2O3 acts as both protective and passivative layer of the Si surface, while the sputtering method using a MoS2 target along with a post-annealing leads to a vertically standing, conformal and crystalline nano-MoS2 layer on Al2O3/n p-Si photocathode. Efficient (0.4 V vs. RHE onset potential and 35.6 mA/cm saturated photocurrent measured under 100 mA/cm Xe lamp illumination) and stable (above 120 h continuous water splitting) photocathode was obtained, which opens the door for the MoS2 catalyst to be applied in photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution in a facile and scalable way.
